text: You're right that doing test directly again RavenDB is slow, but at least the "embedded" mode makes it easy to do.Plus you're testing against the same thing you're running against, so there no issues with there being a difference.BTW nice series, I'm trying to learn ASP.NET MVC and it's really helping.

Yeah - it definitely isn't a criticism of RavenDB, just something that needs pointing out so people don't make my intentional mistake above :)I'm really glad I'm doing a full vertical slice of the project now, not only RavenDB but "these other technologies too", I'd like to think "MS-MVC used right" but I'm sure I'll get a few gotchas commented on as I go through.

First time I see someone validating the login logic in a "ViewValidator" and then using ModelState.Usually see explicit calls to IUserService and just validating that the input isn't empty.Is that a approach you take use else where?

I actually think it's a benefit of Raven. From what I've read, when you want to test other DB solutions you generally end up doing tests against SQLite, rather than against the real DB. At least with RavenDB you're testing the same thing.

Kenny :: It's an odd one I know,  I've got the data there so I use it there,  it also allows me to use the same validation feedback and etc without setting up anything new.In my other projects I just do it in the controller and add a message to a generic messaging system that all pages have the ability to use, but I haven't got access to that here so I don't.Do you have an opinion on this that you'd wish to share? :)

Matt :: It's a valid remark, but remember that with the SQLite solution, we can always flick a switch and run them against MySQL with no changes as part of a set of slower running integration tests, as well as getting some vague sanity checks ran quickly as part of the faster tests.
